data.title: Serving Centerville and Washington Township, OH
data.text:
About the Historical Society

Centerville-Washington History was founded in 1966 as the Centerville Historical Society. To learn more about our organization or to become a member, please choose from the options below.

Who We Are

Membership

Contact Us

**Scholarship for High School Seniors**

2024 Scholarship Winner

Congratulations to the 2024 CWH Scholarship winner, Lauren Miller! Lauren has been involved at Centerville High School in the Key Club that does service work such as packing candy for the troops and making blankets for refugees. She is a member of the American Sign Language Club and the Circle of Friends at CHS where they spend time with children with disabilities. She’s the co-founder and President of the Psychology Club. She played clarinet for two years in the Centerville Jazz Band. Lauren has also been an active volunteer throughout her high school years. She has spent time volunteering at the hospital, through her church, and as a Centerville-Washington History Teen Volunteer. As a Teen Volunteer, Lauren has been involved in Homesteading Ohio, cleaning headstones, and indoor/outdoor beautification of the historic Asahel Wright House.

Lauren plans to attend The Ohio State University in the fall and study molecular genetics program. Centerville-Washington History congratulates Lauren for her hard work and achievements at Centerville High School. Best wishes for continued success at The Ohio State University!

Explore Our History

Centerville is located in the historic Northwest Territory, specifically part of the Symmes’s Purchase which included the land between the two Miami Rivers. After the American Revolution, the Northwest Territory was opened for settlers. The earliest settler in Washington Township was Dr. John Hole. Centerville’s founding fathers, Aaron Nutt, Benjamin Robbins, and Benjamin Archer, traveled from New Jersey, through Pennsylvania, and finally north from Kentucky. The men surveyed John Symmes’s land in 1796 and they chose their own lots. They retrieved their families from Kentucky and settled here over the next couple of years. The rich farmland and limestone quarries made this area an ideal location for starting a new life and many more settlers arrived. Limestone was used in the construction of many early buildings. Several of these historic Stone Buildings still exist today. Montgomery County and Washington Township were established by the legislature when Ohio became a state in 1803. Centerville officially became a town in 1830 and became incorporated as a city in 1968. There are also many important People, Places, and Historical Events of interest that played important roles in shaping our area that have been cataloged and documented by our members.
